description: From an alteration (possibly Scots) of glore, from Middle English glōren, glouren (“to gleam; to glare, glower”); or from glow (“to stare”) (obsolete), and ultimately from a Scandinavian (North Germanic) language. Cognate with Low German gloren (“to flicker; to glimmer”), Middle Dutch gloren, Icelandic glóra. See more at glare.

entries.meaning: An angry glare or stare. [from late 15th c.]
examples: She sure has an awful glower on her face.

verbs.description: glower (third-person singular simple present glowers, present participle glowering, simple past and past participle glowered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To look or stare with anger. [from late 15th c.]

description: From Middle English glouere, equivalent to glow +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: That which glows or emits light.
